title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [3 december 1872]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [3 December 1872]
text: Dec 3 '72tuesdayTuesdaydear walti received the money order this day tuesdayTuesday lou will get the money to morrow) i am pretty smart i am troubled at times with a dissinessdizziness in my head i think sometimes it is owing to having the stoves open and the gassgas) i had mr and mrs bruce and grace to see me the day after thanksgiving they only stayed a short time as they were going home that day at 12 or 1 oclock i was very glad to see them very indeed George went to brooklyn yesterday and returned last evening his work stopped on the water board the 1 of this month he was notified last week by mr adams from the commishonscommissions he has had his pay for three months without their having any work done at stars i beleevebelieve he thinks he will have it again but i dontdon't think its so dreadfulldreadful to only get 8 dollar per day but its put the house question downi have got a letter from han i beleevebelieve i told you in my last letter) so i wrote to her telling her i would send her a box shortly that when the box was sent i would let her know so the day before the box went i got lou to write a few lines as my hand was so bad i couldent i sent a very nice box of things walt the 25 dollars jeff sent me i laid 20 of it out for comfortable things for han and i dontdon't doubt but she appreciates them) but just as the box went i got a letter from mr Heyde i dontdon't know but what i have had as bad ones from him before but the most insulting things he wrote that any one could think of he wrote to me what his obgectobject was i cannot tell after he had said every thing that was insulting he said if there was any thing in the box worth it he would let me know if it came) i sent it a week ago last fridayFriday and i havent heard any thing from them since i paid a dollar and a half for the freight) i have your picture laying beside me as i write you must come christmas Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [3 December 1872]
